titleStmt.title: By my Window have I for Scenery

publicationStmt.p: The Poems of Emily Dickinson, Johnson, 1955

lg.l: By my Window have I for Scenery
Just a Sea -- with a Stem --
GrantGrant If the Bird and the Farmer -- deem it a "Pine" --
The Opinion will do -- for them --
It has no Port, nor a "Line" -- but the Jays --
That split their route to the Sky --
Or a Squirrel, whose giddy Peninsula
May be Better attained --Better attained -- easier reached -- this way --
For Inlands -- the Earth is the under side --
And the upper side -- is the Sun --
And it's Commerce -- if Commerce it have --
Of Spice -- I infer from the Odors borne --
Of it's Voice -- to affirm -- when the Wind is within --
Can the Dumb -- divulgedivulge define the Divine?
The Definition of Melody -- is --
That Definition is none --
It -- suggests to our Faith --
They -- suggest to our Sight --
When the latter -- is put away
I shall meet with Conviction I somewhere met
That Immortality --
Was the Pine at my Window a "Fellow
Of the Royal" Infinity?
Apprehensions -- are God's introductions --
Extended inscrutably --Extended inscrutably -- To be hallowed -- accordingly --
6](That] Ply between it, and the Sky
